Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Unlocking Legged Mobility Through Structured Prediction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) collaborative project will explore a novel interdisciplinary approach to motion planning and control for robust and capable legged machines, inspired by the way that humans navigate challenging terrain, and implemented using computational methods originally developed for space missions. Whether for agriculture, construction, or disaster response, the mobility afforded by legs offers promise for future robots that can go where people go, either in their place or by their side. Yet, for these future robots to succeed in real-world environments they must -- as humans do -- plan and execute purposeful movements, to respond to unexpected obstacles as they arise. Human capabilities in this regard vastly exceed those of modern robots. When humans move through the world, they appear to adjust the level of complexity that they include in their planning to the immediacy of the need. That is, movements that must be executed within the next few moments are visualized in detail, while those that will not occur for some time are abstracted more coarsely. The control scheme created in this project will apply a similar approach in legged robots, to achieve safe, precise movements guided by a long-range strategy. The results will advance the national prosperity and welfare, by enabling legged machines that can make the rapid decisions necessary to keep their balance and avoid falls, improving robustness for practical deployment as first responders, home health aides, explorers, or co-workers.

The project will lay the foundation for a new paradigm of robot control that makes use of a rigorous methodology for optimal control over hierarchical abstractions with a novel computational solution framework. Optimal control over hierarchical abstractions will provide a new tool for control designers, allowing them to strategically enforce consistency between coarse-grained long-term plans and fine-grained near-term control. In legged robots, the absence of a rigorous framework for managing such a challenge has 1) prevented practical hardware implementation of full-model trajectory optimization and 2) limited the robustness of control based on simple models. In this work, these separate approaches will be unified and their combined benefits captured. The envisioned solver uses a new multiple-shooting formulation to reduce problem sensitivity and a new quasi-Newton approximation to reduce runtime. Fundamental efforts as part of the EAGER effort will consider control synthesis for simplified 2D models of quadruped bounding and biped running. The generality of envisioned abstractions for these cases will be studied. Necessary control rates will be assessed in simulation, and a breakdown of the computational requirements for different algorithm components will be determined. This data will be critical to identify further advances to the approach that will be necessary for its future use as an online control method to stabilize locomotion in 3D robots.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project was to explore new algorithms for legged robots to make rapid decisions on the fly, maintaining their balance while responding to unexpected obstacles as they arise.  Algorithms that keep legged robots balanced are often carefully tailored to specific conditions in the research lab. However, as legged robots are dispatched into new roles in society (e.g., transportation, agriculture, health care, and defense), they will inevitably come across novel and previously unencountered situations. This project explored an interdisciplinary approach for legged robots to make rapid decisions in such cases, as inspired by how humans appear to navigate challenging terrain and implemented using computational methods originally developed for planning space missions.

The intellectual merit of the research occurred through two primary outcomes:

The first primary outcome of this work was a new strategy for how robots can reason about the consequences of their actions over extended time horizons. When humans move through the world, they appear to adjust the level of complexity that they include in their planning to the immediacy of the need. That is, movements that must be executed within the next few moments are visualized in detail, while those that will not occur for some time are abstracted more coarsely. This work developed a mathematical formalism for robots to accomplish this same type of reasoning through a strategy named Model Hierarchy Predictive Control and created a new algorithm for optimizing robot actions based on this formalism. The approach was tested in simulation with 2D models of biped and quadruped robots and showed that the new approach enables legged robots to make decisions twice as fast without sacrificing their performance. This new approach to legged robot control worked for both bipeds and quadrupeds without platform-specific changes to the algorithm, which motivates its broad applicability in the field. Preliminary experiments with the MIT Mini Cheetah (see photo) demonstrate the promise of this approach but highlighted a need for further work to address 3D aspects of balance.

The second primary outcome of this work was the translation of algorithms for planning space missions to the case of controlling robotic systems. Space missions are characterized by long time scales that place stringent computational demands on planning algorithms. These demands have led to many algorithmic advances that accelerate planning, and these advances were found to bring speed improvements of 8x-9x over state-of-the-art robotics solutions to the problem. Early work in this assessment found subtle but important differences between the legged robotics and the space mission optimal control applications. Space missions tend to have highly deterministic but relatively simple dynamics that are valid for long time horizons, while terrestrial robotics problems have more complicated and more uncertain dynamics but require much shorter time horizons. Similar to spacecraft dynamics, the robotics problems are highly sensitive, with small changes in the robot's actions, often leading to profoundly different down-stream motions. Motivated by these chaotic dynamics, a secondary outcome of the work was to develop new strategies for robots to exploit small changes in their actions to achieve desired results. These advances in sensitivity analysis showed a 7x improvement over off the shelf strategies in terms of computation time. Additionally, work began on developing new algorithms for the rapid computation of second-order sensitivity information.  These novel methods for including second-order partials are new to the robotics community and enable the use of algorithms for optimal control of robots with strengthened convergence guarantees compared to previous approaches.

Regarding broader impacts, these advances could be transformative for robots operating in unstructured environments out in the real world when delivering packages, tending to crops, or assisting at the scene of a fire. The developed methods could also improve control of prostheses and exoskeletons since their real-time computational challenges are similar. Although the work has targeted legged systems, the structured prediction strategies proposed could also benefit motion planning with other complex systems. Examples include robotics manipulators that need to react quickly to the actions of nearby humans or autonomous vehicles that need to respond rapidly to nearby drivers.

 Overall, this EAGER's key outcome was that the high-risk, high-reward vision set forth by the PIs demonstrated great promise for future robots that can make rapid decisions on the fly. These capabilities will be critical for the envisioned applications of legged systems and have motivated the next steps in research toward this vision.
